course_title: Topics in Texts and Culture: Culture,Embodiment &the Senses
class_notes: Culture, Embodiment, and the Senses offers a historical and cross-cultural analysis of the politics of sensory experience. We will consider Western philosophical debates about mind, brain, emotion, affect, and body, and the historical value placed on sight, reason, and rationality versus other forms of engagement with the world: smell, taste, belief, and touch. The course is designed to help students appreciate the multidimensionality of the sensorium and learn to analyze sensory hierarchies. We will examine the senses cross-culturally and holistically as a means of communication that operates at cultural, social, and political levels. Students will read a range of social theories, ethnographic texts, and literature, and analyze photography, film, and sound.
